speaker: GOWER
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: SCENE I. London. KING RICHARD II's palace.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD II, JOHN OF GAUNT, with other Nobles and Attendants

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Old John of Gaunt, time-honour'd Lancaster,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Hast thou, according to thy oath and band,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Brought hither Henry Hereford thy bold son,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Here to make good the boisterous late appeal,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which then our leisure would not let us hear,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: I have, my liege.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If he appeal the duke on ancient malice;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or worthily, as a good subject should,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: On some known ground of treachery in him?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As near as I could sift him on that argument,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: On some apparent danger seen in him

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Aim'd at your highness, no inveterate malice.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then call them to our presence; face to face,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The accuser and the accused freely speak:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: High-stomach'd are they both, and full of ire,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In rage deaf as the sea, hasty as fire.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE and THOMAS MOWBRAY

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Many years of happy days befal

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Each day still better other's happiness;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Until the heavens, envying earth's good hap,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Add an immortal title to your crown!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We thank you both: yet one but flatters us,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As well appeareth by the cause you come;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Namely to appeal each other of high treason.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: First, heaven be the record to my speech!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In the devotion of a subject's love,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Tendering the precious safety of my prince,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And free from other misbegotten hate,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Come I appellant to this princely presence.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to thee,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And mark my greeting well; for what I speak

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My body shall make good upon this earth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Thou art a traitor and a miscreant,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Too good to be so and too bad to live,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Since the more fair and crystal is the sky,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Once more, the more to aggravate the note,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With a foul traitor's name stuff I thy throat;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And wish, so please my sovereign, ere I move,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What my tongue speaks my right drawn sword may prove.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Let not my cold words here accuse my zeal:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: 'Tis not the trial of a woman's war,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The bitter clamour of two eager tongues,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Yet can I not of such tame patience boast

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: As to be hush'd and nought at all to say:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: First, the fair reverence of your highness curbs me

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: From giving reins and spurs to my free speech;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which else would post until it had return'd

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: These terms of treason doubled down his throat.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Setting aside his high blood's royalty,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And let him be no kinsman to my liege,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I do defy him, and I spit at him;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Call him a slanderous coward and a villain:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which to maintain I would allow him odds,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And meet him, were I tied to run afoot

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Or any other ground inhabitable,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Where ever Englishman durst set his foot.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Mean time let this defend my loyalty,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: By all my hopes, most falsely doth he lie.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Disclaiming here the kindred of the king,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And lay aside my high blood's royalty,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which fear, not reverence, makes thee to except.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If guilty dread have left thee so much strength

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As to take up mine honour's pawn, then stoop:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By that and all the rites of knighthood else,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Will I make good against thee, arm to arm,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What I have spoke, or thou canst worse devise.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I take it up; and by that sword I swear

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I'll answer thee in any fair degree,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Or chivalrous design of knightly trial:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And when I mount, alive may I not light,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: If I be traitor or unjustly fight!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: It must be great that can inherit us

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So much as of a thought of ill in him.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Look, what I speak, my life shall prove it true;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Like a false traitor and injurious villain.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Besides I say and will in battle prove,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or here or elsewhere to the furthest verge

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That ever was survey'd by English eye,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That all the treasons for these eighteen years

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Complotted and contrived in this land

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Further I say and further will maintain

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Upon his bad life to make all this good,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That he did plot the Duke of Gloucester's death,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Suggest his soon-believing adversaries,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And consequently, like a traitor coward,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Sluiced out his innocent soul through streams of blood:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which blood, like sacrificing Abel's, cries,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Even from the tongueless caverns of the earth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To me for justice and rough chastisement;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, by the glorious worth of my descent,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: This arm shall do it, or this life be spent.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How high a pitch his resolution soars!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: O, let my sovereign turn away his face

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And bid his ears a little while be deaf,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Till I have told this slander of his blood,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: How God and good men hate so foul a liar.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Were he my brother, nay, my kingdom's heir,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As he is but my father's brother's son,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now, by my sceptre's awe, I make a vow,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Such neighbour nearness to our sacred blood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Should nothing privilege him, nor partialize

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The unstooping firmness of my upright soul:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Then, Bolingbroke, as low as to thy heart,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Through the false passage of thy throat, thou liest.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Disbursed I duly to his highness' soldiers;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The other part reserved I by consent,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: For that my sovereign liege was in my debt

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Upon remainder of a dear account,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Since last I went to France to fetch his queen:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Now swallow down that lie. For Gloucester's death,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I slew him not; but to my own disgrace

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Neglected my sworn duty in that case.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: For you, my noble Lord of Lancaster,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The honourable father to my foe

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Once did I lay an ambush for your life,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A trespass that doth vex my grieved soul

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: But ere I last received the sacrament

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I did confess it, and exactly begg'd

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Your grace's pardon, and I hope I had it.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: This is my fault: as for the rest appeall'd,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: It issues from the rancour of a villain,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A recreant and most degenerate traitor

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which in myself I boldly will defend;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And interchangeably hurl down my gage

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Upon this overweening traitor's foot,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To prove myself a loyal gentleman

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: In haste whereof, most heartily I pray

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Your highness to assign our trial day.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wrath-kindled gentlemen, be ruled by me;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let's purge this choler without letting blood:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This we prescribe, though no physician;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Deep malice makes too deep incision;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Forget, forgive; conclude and be agreed;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our doctors say this is no month to bleed.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Good uncle, let this end where it begun;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We'll calm the Duke of Norfolk, you your son.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To be a make-peace shall become my age:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And, Norfolk, throw down his.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: When, Harry, when?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Obedience bids I should not bid again.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Norfolk, throw down, we bid; there is no boot.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: My life thou shalt command, but not my shame:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The one my duty owes; but my fair name,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Despite of death that lives upon my grave,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: I am disgraced, impeach'd and baffled here,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Pierced to the soul with slander's venom'd spear,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The which no balm can cure but his heart-blood

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Which breathed this poison.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Rage must be withstood:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Yea, but not change his spots: take but my shame.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: And I resign my gage. My dear dear lord,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: The purest treasure mortal times afford

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Is spotless reputation: that away,

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Men are but gilded loam or painted clay.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: A jewel in a ten-times-barr'd-up chest

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Is a bold spirit in a loyal breast.

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Mine honour is my life; both grow in one:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Take honour from me, and my life is done:

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: Then, dear my liege, mine honour let me try;

speaker: THOMAS MOWBRAY
text_entry: In that I live and for that will I die.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O, God defend my soul from such deep sin!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Before this out-dared dastard? Ere my tongue

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall wound my honour with such feeble wrong,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or sound so base a parle, my teeth shall tear

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The slavish motive of recanting fear,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And spit it bleeding in his high disgrace,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Where shame doth harbour, even in Mowbray's face.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exit JOHN OF GAUNT

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We were not born to sue, but to command;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which since we cannot do to make you friends,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Be ready, as your lives shall answer it,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: There shall your swords and lances arbitrate

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The swelling difference of your settled hate:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since we can not atone you, we shall see

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Justice design the victor's chivalry.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Lord marshal, command our officers at arms

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Be ready to direct these home alarms.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE II. The DUKE OF LANCASTER'S palace.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter JOHN OF GAUNT with DUCHESS

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Alas, the part I had in Woodstock's blood

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Doth more solicit me than your exclaims,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To stir against the butchers of his life!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But since correction lieth in those hands

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Which made the fault that we cannot correct,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Put we our quarrel to the will of heaven;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Who, when they see the hours ripe on earth,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Will rain hot vengeance on offenders' heads.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Hath love in thy old blood no living fire?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Were as seven vials of his sacred blood,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Or seven fair branches springing from one root:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Some of those seven are dried by nature's course,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Some of those branches by the Destinies cut;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But Thomas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: One vial full of Edward's sacred blood,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: One flourishing branch of his most royal root,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Is crack'd, and all the precious liquor spilt,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Is hack'd down, and his summer leaves all faded,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: By envy's hand and murder's bloody axe.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine! that bed, that womb,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That metal, that self-mould, that fashion'd thee

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Yet art thou slain in him: thou dost consent

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In some large measure to thy father's death,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In that thou seest thy wretched brother die,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Who was the model of thy father's life.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Call it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In suffering thus thy brother to be slaughter'd,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Teaching stern murder how to butcher thee:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That which in mean men we intitle patience

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What shall I say? to safeguard thine own life,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: His deputy anointed in His sight,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Hath caused his death: the which if wrongfully,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Let heaven revenge; for I may never lift

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: An angry arm against His minister.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Where then, alas, may I complain myself?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To God, the widow's champion and defence.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Why, then, I will. Farewell, old Gaunt.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Or, if misfortune miss the first career,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Be Mowbray's sins so heavy in his bosom,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: They may break his foaming courser's back,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And throw the rider headlong in the lists,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: A caitiff recreant to my cousin Hereford!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Farewell, old Gaunt: thy sometimes brother's wife

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With her companion grief must end her life.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Sister, farewell; I must to Coventry:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As much good stay with thee as go with me!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Yet one word more: grief boundeth where it falls,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Not with the empty hollowness, but weight:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I take my leave before I have begun,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Commend me to thy brother, Edmund York.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Lo, this is all:--nay, yet depart not so;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Though this be all, do not so quickly go;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I shall remember more. Bid him--ah, what?--

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With all good speed at Plashy visit me.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Alack, and what shall good old York there see

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd walls,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Unpeopled offices, untrodden stones?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And what hear there for welcome but my groans?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Therefore commend me; let him not come there,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: To seek out sorrow that dwells every where.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Desolate, desolate, will I hence and die:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: The last leave of thee takes my weeping eye.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: SCENE III. The lists at Coventry.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Enter the Lord Marshal and the DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: Lord Marshal
text_entry: My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford arm'd?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Yea, at all points; and longs to enter in.

speaker: Lord Marshal

text_entry: The grass whereon thou tread'st the presence strew'd,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The flowers fair ladies, and thy steps no more

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Than a delightful measure or a dance;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The man that mocks at it and sets it light.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O, who can hold a fire in his hand

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By thinking on the frosty Caucasus?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By bare imagination of a feast?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Or wallow naked in December snow

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By thinking on fantastic summer's heat?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O, no! the apprehension of the good

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Than when he bites, but lanceth not the sore.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Come, come, my son, I'll bring thee on thy way:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Had I thy youth and cause, I would not stay.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Where'er I wander, boast of this I can,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: SCENE IV. The court.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD II, with BAGOT and GREEN at one door; and the DUKE OF AUMERLE at another

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We did observe. Cousin Aumerle,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How far brought you high Hereford on his way?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: I brought high Hereford, if you call him so,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: But to the next highway, and there I left him.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And say, what store of parting tears were shed?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Which then blew bitterly against our faces,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Awaked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What said our cousin when you parted with him?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: 'Farewell:'

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And, for my heart disdained that my tongue

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Should so profane the word, that taught me craft

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To counterfeit oppression of such grief

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: That words seem'd buried in my sorrow's grave.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Marry, would the word 'farewell' have lengthen'd hours

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And added years to his short banishment,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: He should have had a volume of farewells;

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: But since it would not, he had none of me.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: When time shall call him home from banishment,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whether our kinsman come to see his friends.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Observed his courtship to the common people;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How he did seem to dive into their hearts

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With humble and familiar courtesy,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What reverence he did throw away on slaves,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wooing poor craftsmen with the craft of smiles

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And patient underbearing of his fortune,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As 'twere to banish their affects with him.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A brace of draymen bid God speed him well

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And had the tribute of his supple knee,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;'

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As were our England in reversion his,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And he our subjects' next degree in hope.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Well, he is gone; and with him go these thoughts.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Now for the rebels which stand out in Ireland,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Expedient manage must be made, my liege,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Ere further leisure yield them further means

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: For their advantage and your highness' loss.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We will ourself in person to this war:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And, for our coffers, with too great a court

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And liberal largess, are grown somewhat light,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We are inforced to farm our royal realm;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The revenue whereof shall furnish us

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For our affairs in hand: if that come short,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whereto, when they shall know what men are rich,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They shall subscribe them for large sums of gold

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And send them after to supply our wants;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For we will make for Ireland presently.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter BUSHY

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Bushy, what news?

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Suddenly taken; and hath sent post haste

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: To entreat your majesty to visit him.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where lies he?

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: At Ely House.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now put it, God, in the physician's mind

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To help him to his grave immediately!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The lining of his coffers shall make coats

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Come, gentlemen, let's all go visit him:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Pray God we may make haste, and come too late!

speaker: All
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: All
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: All
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: All
text_entry: SCENE I. Ely House.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter JOHN OF GAUNT sick, with the DUKE OF YORK, and c

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Will the king come, that I may breathe my last

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Vex not yourself, nor strive not with your breath;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, but they say the tongues of dying men

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Enforce attention like deep harmony:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: He that no more must say is listen'd more

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The setting sun, and music at the close,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As the last taste of sweets, is sweetest last,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Writ in remembrance more than things long past:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The open ear of youth doth always listen;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Report of fashions in proud Italy,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whose manners still our tardy apish nation

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Limps after in base imitation.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So it be new, there's no respect how vile--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Then all too late comes counsel to be heard,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Direct not him whose way himself will choose:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Methinks I am a prophet new inspired

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thus expiring do foretell of him:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For violent fires soon burn out themselves;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Light vanity, insatiate cormorant,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This royal throne of kings, this scepter'd isle,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This earth of majesty, this seat of Mars,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This other Eden, demi-paradise,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This fortress built by Nature for herself

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Against infection and the hand of war,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This happy breed of men, this little world,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This precious stone set in the silver sea,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Which serves it in the office of a wall,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Or as a moat defensive to a house,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Against the envy of less happier lands,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This blessed plot, this earth, this realm, this England,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This nurse, this teeming womb of royal kings,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Fear'd by their breed and famous by their birth,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Renowned for their deeds as far from home,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For Christian service and true chivalry,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As is the sepulchre in stubborn Jewry,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of the world's ransom, blessed Mary's Son,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Dear for her reputation through the world,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Is now leased out, I die pronouncing it,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Like to a tenement or pelting farm:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: England, bound in with the triumphant sea

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That England, that was wont to conquer others,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Hath made a shameful conquest of itself.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: How happy then were my ensuing death!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD II and QUEEN, DUKE OF AUMERLE,  BUSHY, GREEN, BAGOT, LORD ROSS, and LORD WILLOUGHBY

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The king is come: deal mildly with his youth;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What comfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O how that name befits my composition!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Old Gaunt indeed, and gaunt in being old:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For sleeping England long time have I watch'd;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The pleasure that some fathers feed upon,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Can sick men play so nicely with their names?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: No, misery makes sport to mock itself:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: I mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Should dying men flatter with those that live?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: No, no, men living flatter those that die.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, no! thou diest, though I the sicker be.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Now He that made me knows I see thee ill;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thou, too careless patient as thou art,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of those physicians that first wounded thee:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whose compass is no bigger than thy head;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And yet, incaged in so small a verge,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Deposing thee before thou wert possess'd,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Which art possess'd now to depose thyself.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: It were a shame to let this land by lease;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But for thy world enjoying but this land,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Is it not more than shame to shame it so?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Landlord of England art thou now, not king:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A lunatic lean-witted fool,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Presuming on an ague's privilege,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Darest with thy frozen admonition

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With fury from his native residence.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now, by my seat's right royal majesty,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, spare me not, my brother Edward's son,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For that I was his father Edward's son;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That blood already, like the pelican,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Hast thou tapp'd out and drunkenly caroused:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whom fair befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: May be a precedent and witness good

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Join with the present sickness that I have;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thy unkindness be like crooked age,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To crop at once a too long wither'd flower.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: These words hereafter thy tormentors be!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Convey me to my bed, then to my grave:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Love they to live that love and honour have.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Exit, borne off by his Attendants

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And let them die that age and sullens have;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For both hast thou, and both become the grave.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I do beseech your majesty, impute his words

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To wayward sickliness and age in him:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter NORTHUMBERLAND

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What says he?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Nay, nothing; all is said

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His tongue is now a stringless instrument;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Words, life and all, old Lancaster hath spent.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Be York the next that must be bankrupt so!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So much for that. Now for our Irish wars:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which live like venom where no venom else

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But only they have privilege to live.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And for these great affairs do ask some charge,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Towards our assistance we do seize to us

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The plate, corn, revenues and moveables,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possess'd.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: How long shall I be patient? ah, how long

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's banishment

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Not Gaunt's rebukes, nor England's private wrongs,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: About his marriage, nor my own disgrace,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Have ever made me sour my patient cheek,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I am the last of noble Edward's sons,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In war was never lion raged more fierce,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In peace was never gentle lamb more mild,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Than was that young and princely gentleman.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His face thou hast, for even so look'd he,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But when he frown'd, it was against the French

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And not against his friends; his noble hand

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Did will what he did spend and spent not that

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which his triumphant father's hand had won;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His hands were guilty of no kindred blood,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But bloody with the enemies of his kin.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: O Richard! York is too far gone with grief,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Or else he never would compare between.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Why, uncle, what's the matter?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: O my liege,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Pardon me, if you please; if n ot, I, pleased

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Not to be pardon'd, am content withal.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Is not Gaunt dead, and doth not Hereford live?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Was not Gaunt just, and is not Harry true?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Did not the one deserve to have an heir?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Is not his heir a well-deserving son?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His charters and his customary rights;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Be not thyself; for how art thou a king

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But by fair sequence and succession?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now, afore God--God forbid I say true!--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: If you do wrongfully seize Hereford's rights,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Call in the letters patent that he hath

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: By his attorneys-general to sue

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His livery, and deny his offer'd homage,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: You pluck a thousand dangers on your head,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: You lose a thousand well-disposed hearts

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And prick my tender patience, to those thoughts

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which honour and allegiance cannot think.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Think what you will, we seize into our hands

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I'll not be by the while: my liege, farewell:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: What will ensue hereof, there's none can tell;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But by bad courses may be understood

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That their events can never fall out good.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Bid him repair to us to Ely House

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To see this business. To-morrow next

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And we create, in absence of ourself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our uncle York lord governor of England;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For he is just and always loved us well.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Come on, our queen: to-morrow must we part;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Be merry, for our time of stay is short

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt KING RICHARD II, QUEEN, DUKE OF AUMERLE, BUSHY, GREEN, and BAGOT

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: And living too; for now his son is duke.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Barely in title, not in revenue.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Richly in both, if justice had her right.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: My heart is great; but it must break with silence,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford?

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: If it be so, out with it boldly, man;

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: No good at all that I can do for him;

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Unless you call it good to pity him,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Bereft and gelded of his patrimony.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: In him, a royal prince, and many moe

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Of noble blood in this declining land.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The king is not himself, but basely led

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: By flatterers; and what they will inform,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That will the king severely prosecute

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: 'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: And daily new exactions are devised,

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what:

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But basely yielded upon compromise

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: He hath not money for these Irish wars,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: His burthenous taxations notwithstanding,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His noble kinsman: most degenerate king!

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: We see the wind sit sore upon our sails,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And yet we strike not, but securely perish.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: We see the very wreck that we must suffer;

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: And unavoided is the danger now,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: For suffering so the causes of our wreck.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: I spy life peering; but I dare not say

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: How near the tidings of our comfort is.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Be confident to speak, Northumberland:

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: We three are but thyself; and, speaking so,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Then thus: I have from Port le Blanc, a bay

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: In Brittany, received intelligence

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That late broke from the Duke of Exeter,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton and Francis Quoint,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: All these well furnish'd by the Duke of Bretagne

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: With eight tall ships, three thousand men of war,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Are making hither with all due expedience

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And shortly mean to touch our northern shore:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The first departing of the king for Ireland.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Imp out our drooping country's broken wing,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Redeem from broking pawn the blemish'd crown,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Wipe off the dust that hides our sceptre's gilt

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And make high majesty look like itself,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Away with me in post to Ravenspurgh;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But if you faint, as fearing to do so,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Stay and be secret, and myself will go.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: To horse, to horse! urge doubts to them that fear.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: SCENE II. The palace.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Enter QUEEN, BUSHY, and BAGOT

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Madam, your majesty is too much sad:

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: You promised, when you parted with the king,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: To lay aside life-harming heaviness

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: And entertain a cheerful disposition.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To please the king I did; to please myself

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: I cannot do it; yet I know no cause

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Why I should welcome such a guest as grief,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: As my sweet Richard: yet again, methinks,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fortune's womb,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Is coming towards me, and my inward soul

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: With nothing trembles: at some thing it grieves,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: More than with parting from my lord the king.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Which shows like grief itself, but is not so;

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Divides one thing entire to many objects;

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Distinguish form: so your sweet majesty,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Looking awry upon your lord's departure,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail;

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadows

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Of what it is not. Then, thrice-gracious queen,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: More than your lord's departure weep not: more's not seen;

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Which for things true weeps things imaginary.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: It may be so; but yet my inward soul

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: I cannot but be sad; so heavy sad

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: As, though on thinking on no thought I think,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: 'Tis nothing but conceit, my gracious lady.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: 'Tis nothing less: conceit is still derived

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: From some forefather grief; mine is not so,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: For nothing had begot my something grief;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: 'Tis in reversion that I do possess;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: But what it is, that is not yet known; what

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: I cannot name; 'tis nameless woe, I wot.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Enter GREEN

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: God save your majesty! and well met, gentlemen:

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: I hope the king is not yet shipp'd for Ireland.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Why hopest thou so? 'tis better hope he is;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipp'd?

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: That he, our hope, might have retired his power,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: And driven into despair an enemy's hope,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Who strongly hath set footing in this land:

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: And with uplifted arms is safe arrived

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: At Ravenspurgh.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Now God in heaven forbid!

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Ah, madam, 'tis too true: and that is worse,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: The Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Why have you not proclaim'd Northumberland

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: And all the rest revolted faction traitors?

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship,

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: And all the household servants fled with him

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: To Bolingbroke.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: So, Green, thou art the midwife to my woe,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And Bolingbroke my sorrow's dismal heir:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Now hath my soul brought forth her prodigy,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And I, a gasping new-deliver'd mother,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Have woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow join'd.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Despair not, madam.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Who shall hinder me?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: I will despair, and be at enmity

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: With cozening hope: he is a flatterer,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: A parasite, a keeper back of death,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Who gently would dissolve the bands of life,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Which false hope lingers in extremity.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Here comes the Duke of York.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: With signs of war about his aged neck:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: O, full of careful business are his looks!

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Uncle, for God's sake, speak comfortable words.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Your husband, he is gone to save far off,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whilst others come to make him lose at home:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Here am I left to underprop his land,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Who, weak with age, cannot support myself:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now comes the sick hour that his surfeit made;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now shall he try his friends that flatter'd him.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord, your son was gone before I came.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: He was? Why, so! go all which way it will!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The nobles they are fled, the commons they are cold,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And will, I fear, revolt on Hereford's side.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Sirrah, get thee to Plashy, to my sister Gloucester;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Bid her send me presently a thousand pound:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Hold, take my ring.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: To-day, as I came by, I called there;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: But I shall grieve you to report the rest.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: What is't, knave?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: An hour before I came, the duchess died.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: God for his mercy! what a tide of woes

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Comes rushing on this woeful land at once!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I know not what to do: I would to God,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So my untruth had not provoked him to it,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The king had cut off my head with my brother's.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: How shall we do for money for these wars?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Come, sister,--cousin, I would say--pray, pardon me.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And bring away the armour that is there.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exit Servant

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Gentlemen, will you go muster men?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: If I know how or which way to order these affairs

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thus thrust disorderly into my hands,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Never believe me. Both are my kinsmen:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The one is my sovereign, whom both my oath

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And duty bids defend; the other again

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Is my kinsman, whom the king hath wrong'd,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whom conscience and my kindred bids to right.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Well, somewhat we must do. Come, cousin, I'll

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Dispose of you.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Gentlemen, go, muster up your men,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And meet me presently at Berkeley.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I should to Plashy too;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But time will not permit: all is uneven,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And every thing is left at six and seven.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt DUKE OF YORK and QUEEN

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: But none returns. For us to levy power

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Proportionable to the enemy

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Is all unpossible.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Besides, our nearness to the king in love

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Is near the hate of those love not the king.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: And that's the wavering commons: for their love

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: If judgement lie in them, then so do we,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Because we ever have been near the king.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Well, I will for refuge straight to Bristol castle:

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: The Earl of Wiltshire is already there.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Thither will I with you; for little office

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: The hateful commons will perform for us,

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Except like curs to tear us all to pieces.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Will you go along with us?

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: No; I will to Ireland to his majesty.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: We three here art that ne'er shall meet again.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Alas, poor duke! the task he undertakes

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Is numbering sands and drinking oceans dry:

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Well, we may meet again.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: I fear me, never.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: SCENE III. Wilds in Gloucestershire.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE and NORTHUMBERLAND, with Forces

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Believe me, noble lord,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: I am a stranger here in Gloucestershire:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: These high wild hills and rough uneven ways

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And yet your fair discourse hath been as sugar,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Making the hard way sweet and delectable.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But I bethink me what a weary way

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will be found

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: In Ross and Willoughby, wanting your company,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which, I protest, hath very much beguiled

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The tediousness and process of my travel:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The present benefit which I possess;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And hope to joy is little less in joy

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Than hope enjoy'd: by this the weary lords

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: By sight of what I have, your noble company.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of much less value is my company

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Than your good words. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter HENRY PERCY

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: It is my son, young Harry Percy,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Harry, how fares your uncle?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Why, is he not with the queen?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: No, my good Lord; he hath forsook the court,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Broken his staff of office and dispersed

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: The household of the king.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: What was his reason?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: He was not so resolved when last we spake together.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: To offer service to the Duke of Hereford,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: What power the Duke of York had levied there;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: No, my good lord, for that is not forgot

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: I never in my life did look on him.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: My gracious lord, I tender you my service,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Such as it is, being tender, raw and young:

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Which elder days shall ripen and confirm

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: To more approved service and desert.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I count myself in nothing else so happy

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As in a soul remembering my good friends;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, as my fortune ripens with thy love,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: It shall be still thy true love's recompense:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: How far is it to Berkeley? and what stir

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Keeps good old York there with his men of war?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: There stands the castle, by yon tuft of trees,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: None else of name and noble estimate.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Enter LORD ROSS and LORD WILLOUGHBY

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: A banish'd traitor: all my treasury

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Is yet but unfelt thanks, which more enrich'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall be your love and labour's recompense.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: And far surmounts our labour to attain it.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which, till my infant fortune comes to years,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Stands for my bounty. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter LORD BERKELEY

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I guess.

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My lord, my answer is--to Lancaster;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And I am come to seek that name in England;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And I must find that title in your tongue,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Before I make reply to aught you say.

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: To raze one title of your honour out:

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: To you, my lord, I come, what lord you will,

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: From the most gracious regent of this land,

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: To take advantage of the absent time

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: And fright our native peace with self-born arms.

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK attended

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I shall not need transport my words by you;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Show me thy humble heart, and not thy knee,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whose duty is deceiveable and false.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious uncle--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Tut, tut!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.'

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In an ungracious mouth is but profane.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Why have those banish'd and forbidden legs

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But then more 'why?' why have they dared to march

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So many miles upon her peaceful bosom,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Frighting her pale-faced villages with war

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And ostentation of despised arms?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Why, foolish boy, the king is left behind,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And in my loyal bosom lies his power.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Were I but now the lord of such hot youth

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As when brave Gaunt, thy father, and myself

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: From forth the ranks of many thousand French,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: O, then how quickly should this arm of mine.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And minister correction to thy fault!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious uncle, let me know my fault:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: On what condition stands it and wherein?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Even in condition of the worst degree,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In gross rebellion and detested treason:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Before the expiration of thy time,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In braving arms against thy sovereign.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But as I come, I come for Lancaster.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You are my father, for methinks in you

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If that my cousin king be King of England,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Had you first died, and he been thus trod down,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I am denied to sue my livery here,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And yet my letters-patents give me leave:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And these and all are all amiss employ'd.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What would you have me do? I am a subject,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And therefore, personally I lay my claim

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To my inheritance of free descent.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The noble duke hath been too much abused.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: It stands your grace upon to do him right.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Base men by his endowments are made great.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: My lords of England, let me tell you this:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And laboured all I could to do him right;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But in this kind to come, in braving arms,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Be his own carver and cut out his way,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To find out right with wrong, it may not be;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And you that do abet him in this kind

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The noble duke hath sworn his coming is

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But for his own; and for the right of that

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: We all have strongly sworn to give him aid;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Well, well, I see the issue of these arms:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I cannot mend it, I must needs confess,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Because my power is weak and all ill left:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But if I could, by Him that gave me life,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I would attach you all and make you stoop

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Unto the sovereign mercy of the king;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But since I cannot, be it known to you

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I do remain as neuter. So, fare you well;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Unless you please to enter in the castle

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And there repose you for this night.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: An offer, uncle, that we will accept:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But we must win your grace to go with us

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To Bristol castle, which they say is held

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By Bushy, Bagot and their complices,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The caterpillars of the commonwealth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which I have sworn to weed and pluck away.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For I am loath to break our country's laws.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Things past redress are now with me past care.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: SCENE IV. A camp in Wales.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Enter EARL OF SALISBURY and a Welsh Captain
