speaker: Captain
text_entry: My lord of Salisbury, we have stay'd ten days,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And hardly kept our countrymen together,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And yet we hear no tidings from the king;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Therefore we will disperse ourselves: farewell.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman:

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: 'Tis thought the king is dead; we will not stay.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The bay-trees in our country are all wither'd

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And meteors fright the fixed stars of heaven;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The pale-faced moon looks bloody on the earth

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And lean-look'd prophets whisper fearful change;

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Rich men look sad and ruffians dance and leap,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The one in fear to lose what they enjoy,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: The other to enjoy by rage and war:

speaker: Captain
text_entry: These signs forerun the death or fall of kings.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: As well assured Richard their king is dead.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Ah, Richard, with the eyes of heavy mind

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: I see thy glory like a shooting star

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Fall to the base earth from the firmament.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Witnessing storms to come, woe and unrest:

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: SCENE I. Bristol. Before the castle.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE, DUKE OF YORK,  NORTHUMBERLAND, LORD ROSS, HENRY PERCY, LORD WILLOUGHBY, with BUSHY and GREEN, prisoners

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Bring forth these men.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls--

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Since presently your souls must part your bodies--

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With too much urging your pernicious lives,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blood

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: From off my hands, here in the view of men

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I will unfold some causes of your deaths.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You have misled a prince, a royal king,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: A happy gentleman in blood and lineaments,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By you unhappied and disfigured clean:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You have in manner with your sinful hours

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Made a divorce betwixt his queen and him,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Broke the possession of a royal bed

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And stain'd the beauty of a fair queen's cheeks

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With tears drawn from her eyes by your foul wrongs.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Myself, a prince by fortune of my birth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Near to the king in blood, and near in love

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Till you did make him misinterpret me,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Have stoop'd my neck under your injuries,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And sigh'd my English breath in foreign clouds,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Eating the bitter bread of banishment;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Whilst you have fed upon my signories,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Dispark'd my parks and fell'd my forest woods,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: From my own windows torn my household coat,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Razed out my imprese, leaving me no sign,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Save men's opinions and my living blood,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To show the world I am a gentleman.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: This and much more, much more than twice all this,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Condemns you to the death. See them deliver'd over

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To execution and the hand of death.

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: More welcome is the stroke of death to me

speaker: BUSHY
text_entry: Than Bolingbroke to England. Lords, farewell.

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: My comfort is that heaven will take our souls

speaker: GREEN
text_entry: And plague injustice with the pains of hell.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND and others, with the prisoners

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Uncle, you say the queen is at your house;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Tell her I send to her my kind commends;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Take special care my greetings be deliver'd.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'd

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: With letters of your love to her at large.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Thank, gentle uncle. Come, lords, away.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To fight with Glendower and his complices:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Awhile to work, and after holiday.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: SCENE II. The coast of Wales. A castle in view.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Drums; flourish and colours. Enter KING RICHARD II, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, DUKE OF AUMERLE, and Soldiers

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Yea, my lord. How brooks your grace the air,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: After your late tossing on the breaking seas?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To stand upon my kingdom once again.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As a long-parted mother with her child

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And do thee favours with my royal hands.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But let thy spiders, that suck up thy venom,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And heavy-gaited toads lie in their way,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which with usurping steps do trample thee:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Yield stinging nettles to mine enemies;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And when they from thy bosom pluck a flower,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Guard it, I pray thee, with a lurking adder

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whose double tongue may with a mortal touch

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mock not my senseless conjuration, lords:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This earth shall have a feeling and these stones

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Prove armed soldiers, ere her native king

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Hath power to keep you king in spite of all.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The means that heaven yields must be embraced,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And not neglected; else, if heaven would,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And we will not, heaven's offer we refuse,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The proffer'd means of succor and redress.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: He means, my lord, that we are too remiss;

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Whilst Bolingbroke, through our security,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Grows strong and great in substance and in power.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That when the searching eye of heaven is hid,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Behind the globe, that lights the lower world,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In murders and in outrage, boldly here;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But when from under this terrestrial ball

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And darts his light through every guilty hole,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then murders, treasons and detested sins,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The cloak of night being pluck'd from off their backs,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Who all this while hath revell'd in the night

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall see us rising in our throne, the east,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His treasons will sit blushing in his face,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Not able to endure the sight of day,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But self-affrighted tremble at his sin.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Not all the water in the rough rude sea

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Can wash the balm off from an anointed king;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The breath of worldly men cannot depose

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The deputy elected by the Lord:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A glorious angel: then, if angels fight,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Weak men must fall, for heaven still guards the right.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter EARL OF SALISBURY

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Welcome, my lord how far off lies your power?

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: And bids me speak of nothing but despair.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: One day too late, I fear me, noble lord,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth:

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: O, call back yesterday, bid time return,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late,

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: O'erthrows thy joys, friends, fortune and thy state:

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead.

speaker: EARL OF SALISBURY
text_entry: Are gone to Bolingbroke, dispersed and fled.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But now the blood of twenty thousand men

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Did triumph in my face, and they are fled;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And, till so much blood thither come again,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Have I not reason to look pale and dead?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: All souls that will be safe fly from my side,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For time hath set a blot upon my pride.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I had forgot myself; am I not king?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: At thy great glory. Look not to the ground,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ye favourites of a king: are we not high?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: High be our thoughts: I know my uncle York

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Hath power enough to serve our turn. But who comes here?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter SIR STEPHEN SCROOP

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: More health and happiness betide my liege

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Than can my care-tuned tongue deliver him!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And what loss is it to be rid of care?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Greater he shall not be; if he serve God,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Revolt our subjects? that we cannot mend;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They break their faith to God as well as us:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The worst is death, and death will have his day.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: To bear the tidings of calamity.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Like an unseasonable stormy day,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Which makes the silver rivers drown their shores,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: As if the world were all dissolved to tears,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: So high above his limits swells the rage

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Of Bolingbroke, covering your fearful land

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: With hard bright steel and hearts harder than steel.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: White-beards have arm'd their thin and hairless scalps

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Against thy majesty; boys, with women's voices,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Strive to speak big and clap their female joints

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: In stiff unwieldy arms against thy crown:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: The very beadsmen learn to bend their bows

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Of double-fatal yew against thy state;

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Against thy seat: both young and old rebel,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And all goes worse than I have power to tell.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? where is Bagot?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What is become of Bushy? where is Green?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That they have let the dangerous enemy

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I warrant they have made peace with Bolingbroke.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would they make peace? terrible hell make war

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Upon their spotted souls for this offence!

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Sweet love, I see, changing his property,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Is Bushy, Green, and the Earl of Wiltshire dead?

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Ay, all of them at Bristol lost their heads.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Where is the duke my father with his power?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No matter where; of comfort no man speak:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let's choose executors and talk of wills:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet not so, for what can we bequeath

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Save our deposed bodies to the ground?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And nothing can we call our own but death

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And that small model of the barren earth

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And tell sad stories of the death of kings;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How some have been deposed; some slain in war,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Some poison'd by their wives: some sleeping kill'd;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: All murder'd: for within the hollow crown

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That rounds the mortal temples of a king

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Scoffing his state and grinning at his pomp,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Allowing him a breath, a little scene,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To monarchize, be fear'd and kill with looks,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Infusing him with self and vain conceit,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As if this flesh which walls about our life,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Were brass impregnable, and humour'd thus

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Comes at the last and with a little pin

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Bores through his castle wall, and farewell king!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With solemn reverence: throw away respect,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tradition, form and ceremonious duty,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For you have but mistook me all this while:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I live with bread like you, feel want,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Taste grief, need friends: subjected thus,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How can you say to me, I am a king?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: But presently prevent the ways to wail.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And so your follies fight against yourself.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And fight and die is death destroying death;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My father hath a power; inquire of him

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And learn to make a body of a limb.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To change blows with thee for our day of doom.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This ague fit of fear is over-blown;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: An easy task it is to win our own.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Say, Scroop, where lies our uncle with his power?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Speak sweetly, man, although thy looks be sour.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Men judge by the complexion of the sky

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: The state and inclination of the day:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: So may you by my dull and heavy eye,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: I play the torturer, by small and small

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Your uncle York is join'd with Bolingbroke,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And all your northern castles yielded up,

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: And all your southern gentlemen in arms

speaker: SIR STEPHEN SCROOP
text_entry: Upon his party.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou hast said enough.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of that sweet way I was in to despair!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What say you now? what comfort have we now?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That bids me be of comfort any more.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That power I have, discharge; and let them go

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To ear the land that hath some hope to grow,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For I have none: let no man speak again

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To alter this, for counsel is but vain.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My liege, one word.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He does me double wrong

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Discharge my followers: let them hence away,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE III. Wales. Before Flint castle.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter, with drum and colours, HENRY BOLINGBROKE, DUKE OF YORK, NORTHUMBERLAND, Attendants, and forces

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So that by this intelligence we learn

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With some few private friends upon this coast.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The news is very fair and good, my lord:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Richard not far from hence hath hid his head.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: It would beseem the Lord Northumberland

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: When such a sacred king should hide his head.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Your grace mistakes; only to be brief

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Left I his title out.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The time hath been,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Would you have been so brief with him, he would

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Have been so brief with you, to shorten you,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For taking so the head, your whole head's length.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Take not, good cousin, further than you should.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Lest you mistake the heavens are o'er our heads.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Against their will. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter HENRY PERCY

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Welcome, Harry: what, will not this castle yield?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: The castle royally is mann'd, my lord,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Against thy entrance.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Royally!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Why, it contains no king?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Yes, my good lord,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: It doth contain a king; King Richard lies

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Within the limits of yon lime and stone:

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: O, belike it is the Bishop of Carlisle.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Noble lords,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Henry Bolingbroke

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And sends allegiance and true faith of heart

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To his most royal person, hither come

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Even at his feet to lay my arms and power,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Provided that my banishment repeal'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And lands restored again be freely granted:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If not, I'll use the advantage of my power

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And lay the summer's dust with showers of blood

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The which, how far off from the mind of Bolingbroke

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: It is, such crimson tempest should bedrench

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The fresh green lap of fair King Richard's land,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My stooping duty tenderly shall show.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go, signify as much, while here we march

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Let's march without the noise of threatening drum,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That from this castle's tatter'd battlements

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Our fair appointments may be well perused.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Methinks King Richard and myself should meet

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With no less terror than the elements

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of fire and water, when their thundering shock

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My waters; on the earth, and not on him.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: March on, and mark King Richard how he looks.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Parle without, and answer within. Then a flourish.  Enter on the walls, KING RICHARD II, the BISHOP OF  CARLISLE, DUKE OF AUMERLE, SIR STEPHEN SCROOP, and EARL OF SALISBURY

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: See, see, King Richard doth himself appear,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As doth the blushing discontented sun

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: From out the fiery portal of the east,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: When he perceives the envious clouds are bent

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To dim his glory and to stain the track

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of his bright passage to the occident.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As bright as is the eagle's, lightens forth

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That any harm should stain so fair a show!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We are amazed; and thus long have we stood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To watch the fearful bending of thy knee,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To NORTHUMBERLAND

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And if we be, how dare thy joints forget

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To pay their awful duty to our presence?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If we be not, show us the hand of God

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That hath dismissed us from our stewardship;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For well we know, no hand of blood and bone

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Unless he do profane, steal, or usurp.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And though you think that all, as you have done,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Have torn their souls by turning them from us,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And we are barren and bereft of friends;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Yet know, my master, God omnipotent,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is mustering in his clouds on our behalf

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Armies of pestilence; and they shall strike

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your children yet unborn and unbegot,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That lift your vassal hands against my head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And threat the glory of my precious crown.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tell Bolingbroke--for yond methinks he stands--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That every stride he makes upon my land

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is dangerous treason: he is come to open

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The purple testament of bleeding war;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But ere the crown he looks for live in peace,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ten thousand bloody crowns of mothers' sons

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall ill become the flower of England's face,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Change the complexion of her maid-pale peace

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To scarlet indignation and bedew

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Her pastures' grass with faithful English blood.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The king of heaven forbid our lord the king

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Should so with civil and uncivil arms

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Be rush'd upon! Thy thrice noble cousin

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Harry Bolingbroke doth humbly kiss thy hand;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the honourable tomb he swears,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That stands upon your royal grandsire's bones,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the royalties of both your bloods,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Currents that spring from one most gracious head,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the buried hand of warlike Gaunt,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And by the worth and honour of himself,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Comprising all that may be sworn or said,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His coming hither hath no further scope

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Than for his lineal royalties and to beg

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Enfranchisement immediate on his kn ees:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which on thy royal party granted once,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His glittering arms he will commend to rust,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His barbed steeds to stables, and his heart

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To faithful service of your majesty.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: This swears he, as he is a prince, is just;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And, as I am a gentleman, I credit him.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Northumberland, say thus the king returns:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His noble cousin is right welcome hither;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And all the number of his fair demands

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall be accomplish'd without contradiction:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With all the gracious utterance thou hast

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To look so poorly and to speak so fair?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall we call back Northumberland, and send

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Defiance to the traitor, and so die?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle words

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That laid the sentence of dread banishment

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: On yon proud man, should take it off again

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With words of sooth! O that I were as great

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As is my grief, or lesser than my name!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or that I could forget what I have been,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or not remember what I must be now!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Swell'st thou, proud heart? I'll give thee scope to beat,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Northumberland comes back from Bolingbroke.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What must the king do now? must he submit?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The king shall do it: must he be deposed?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The king shall be contented: must he lose

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The name of king? o' God's name, let it go:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I'll give my jewels for a set of beads,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My gorgeous palace for a hermitage,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My gay apparel for an almsman's gown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My figured goblets for a dish of wood,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My sceptre for a palmer's walking staff,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My subjects for a pair of carved saints

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And my large kingdom for a little grave,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A little little grave, an obscure grave;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or I'll be buried in the king's highway,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Some way of common trade, where subjects' feet

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: May hourly trample on their sovereign's head;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For on my heart they tread now whilst I live;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And buried once, why not upon my head?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Aumerle, thou weep'st, my tender-hearted cousin!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We'll make foul weather with despised tears;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And make a dearth in this revolting land.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Or shall we play the wantons with our woes,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And make some pretty match with shedding tears?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As thus, to drop them still upon one place,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Till they have fretted us a pair of graves

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Within the earth; and, therein laid,--there lies

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Two kinsmen digg'd their graves with weeping eyes.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would not this ill do well? Well, well, I see

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I talk but idly, and you laugh at me.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Most mighty prince, my Lord Northumberland,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What says King Bolingbroke? will his majesty

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: You make a leg, and Bolingbroke says ay.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord, in the base court he doth attend

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To speak with you; may it please you to come down.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wanting the manage of unruly jades.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To come at traitors' calls and do them grace.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In the base court? Come down? Down, court!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: down, king!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For night-owls shriek where mounting larks

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: should sing.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt from above

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What says his majesty?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sorrow and grief of heart

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yet he is come.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD and his attendants below

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Stand all apart,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And show fair duty to his majesty.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: He kneels down

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious lord,--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To make the base earth proud with kissing it:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Me rather had my heart might feel your love

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Than my unpleased eye see your courtesy.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Up, cousin, up; your heart is up, I know,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thus high at least, although your knee be low.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So far be mine, my most redoubted lord,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As my true service shall deserve your love.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Well you deserve: they well deserve to have,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That know the strong'st and surest way to get.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Uncle, give me your hands: nay, dry your eyes;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tears show their love, but want their remedies.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Cousin, I am too young to be your father,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though you are old enough to be my heir.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What you will have, I'll give, and willing too;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For do we must what force will have us do.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Set on towards London, cousin, is it so?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Yea, my good lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then I must not say no.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE IV. LANGLEY. The DUKE OF YORK's garden.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter the QUEEN and two Ladies

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What sport shall we devise here in this garden,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To drive away the heavy thought of care?

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, we'll play at bowls.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: 'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And that my fortune rubs against the bias.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, we'll dance.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: My legs can keep no measure in delight,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Therefore, no dancing, girl; some other sport.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, we'll tell tales.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Of sorrow or of joy?

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Of either, madam.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Of neither, girl:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: For of joy, being altogether wanting,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: It doth remember me the more of sorrow;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Or if of grief, being altogether had,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: It adds more sorrow to my want of joy:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: For what I have I need not to repeat;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And what I want it boots not to complain.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, I'll sing.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: 'Tis well that thou hast cause

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: But thou shouldst please me better, wouldst thou weep.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: I could weep, madam, would it do you good.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And I could sing, would weeping do me good,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And never borrow any tear of thee.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Enter a Gardener, and two Servants

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: But stay, here come the gardeners:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Let's step into the shadow of these trees.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: My wretchedness unto a row of pins,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: They'll talk of state; for every one doth so

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: QUEEN and Ladies retire

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Which, like unruly children, make their sire

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Give some supportance to the bending twigs.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Go thou, and like an executioner,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That look too lofty in our commonwealth:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: All must be even in our government.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: You thus employ'd, I will go root away

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: The noisome weeds, which without profit suck

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Why should we in the compass of a pale

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Keep law and form and due proportion,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Showing, as in a model, our firm estate,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: When our sea-walled garden, the whole land,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Is full of weeds, her fairest flowers choked up,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Her fruit-trees all upturned, her hedges ruin'd,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Her knots disorder'd and her wholesome herbs

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Swarming with caterpillars?

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Hold thy peace:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd spring

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That seem'd in eating him to hold him up,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: What, are they dead?

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: They are; and Bolingbroke

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Hath seized the wasteful king. O, what pity is it

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: As we this garden! We at time of year

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: With too much riches it confound itself:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Had he done so to great and growing men,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: They might have lived to bear and he to taste

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: We lop away, that bearing boughs may live:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Had he done so, himself had borne the crown,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: What, think you then the king shall be deposed?

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Depress'd he is already, and deposed

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: 'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That tell black tidings.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking!

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Coming forward

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What Eve, what serpent, hath suggested thee

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To make a second fall of cursed man?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Divine his downfall? Say, where, when, and how,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Camest thou by this ill tidings? speak, thou wretch.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Pardon me, madam: little joy have I

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: King Richard, he is in the mighty hold

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: In your lord's scale is nothing but himself,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: And some few vanities that make him light;

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: But in the balance of great Bolingbroke,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Besides himself, are all the English peers,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: And with that odds he weighs King Richard down.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Post you to London, and you will find it so;

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: I speak no more than every one doth know.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Nimble mischance, that art so light of foot,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Doth not thy embassage belong to me,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And am I last that knows it? O, thou think'st

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To serve me last, that I may longest keep

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Thy sorrow in my breast. Come, ladies, go,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To meet at London London's king in woe.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What, was I born to this, that my sad look

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Gardener, for telling me these news of woe,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Exeunt QUEEN and Ladies

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse,

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: I would my skill were subject to thy curse.

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Here did she fall a tear; here in this place

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace:

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen,

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: In the remembrance of a weeping queen.

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: SCENE I. Westminster Hall.

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Enter, as to the Parliament, HENRY BOLINGBROKE,  DUKE OF AUMERLE, NORTHUMBERLAND, HENRY PERCY, LORD  FITZWATER, DUKE OF SURREY, the BISHOP OF CARLISLE,  the Abbot Of Westminster, and another Lord, Herald, Officers, and BAGOT

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Call forth Bagot.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Who wrought it with the king, and who perform'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The bloody office of his timeless end.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Then set before my face the Lord Aumerle.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: My Lord Aumerle, I know your daring tongue

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Scorns to unsay what once it hath deliver'd.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: In that dead time when Gloucester's death was plotted,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: I heard you say, 'Is not my arm of length,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: That reacheth from the restful English court

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: As far as Calais, to mine uncle's head?'

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Amongst much other talk, that very time,

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: I heard you say that you had rather refuse

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: The offer of an hundred thousand crowns

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Than Bolingbroke's return to England;

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Adding withal how blest this land would be

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: In this your cousin's death.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Princes and noble lords,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: What answer shall I make to this base man?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Shall I so much dishonour my fair stars,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: On equal terms to give him chastisement?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: With the attainder of his slanderous lips.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: There is my gage, the manual seal of death,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: That marks thee out for hell: I say, thou liest,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And will maintain what thou hast said is false

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: In thy heart-blood, though being all too base

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To stain the temper of my knightly sword.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Excepting one, I would he were the best

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: In all this presence that hath moved me so.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: If that thy valour stand on sympathy,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine:

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: By that fair sun which shows me where thou stand'st,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: I heard thee say, and vauntingly thou spakest it

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: That thou wert cause of noble Gloucester's death.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: If thou deny'st it twenty times, thou liest;

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And I will turn thy falsehood to thy heart,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Where it was forged, with my rapier's point.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Aumerle, thou liest; his honour is as true

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: In this appeal as thou art all unjust;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And that thou art so, there I throw my gage,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: To prove it on thee to the extremest point

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Of mortal breathing: seize it, if thou darest.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: An if I do not, may my hands rot off

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: And never brandish more revengeful steel

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Over the glittering helmet of my foe!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I task the earth to the like, forsworn Aumerle;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And spur thee on with full as many lies

speaker: Lord
text_entry: As may be holloa'd in thy treacherous ear

speaker: Lord
text_entry: From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn;

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Who sets me else? by heaven, I'll throw at all:

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: I have a thousand spirits in one breast,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To answer twenty thousand such as you.

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember well

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: The very time Aumerle and you did talk.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: 'Tis very true: you were in presence then;

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And you can witness with me this is true.

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Surrey, thou liest.

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: Dishonourable boy!

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: That lie shall lie so heavy on my sword,

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: That it shall render vengeance and revenge

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: In earth as quiet as thy father's skull:

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: In proof whereof, there is my honour's pawn;

speaker: DUKE OF SURREY
text_entry: Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse!

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And spit upon him, whilst I say he lies,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: And lies, and lies: there is my bond of faith,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: To tie thee to my strong correction.

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: As I intend to thrive in this new world,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal:

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Besides, I heard the banish'd Norfolk say

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: That thou, Aumerle, didst send two of thy men

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: To execute the noble duke at Calais.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Some honest Christian trust me with a gage

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: That Norfolk lies: here do I throw down this,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: If he may be repeal'd, to try his honour.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: These differences shall all rest under gage

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, though mine enemy, restored again

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To all his lands and signories: when he's return'd,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Against Aumerle we will enforce his trial.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Many a time hath banish'd Norfolk fought

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Streaming the ensign of the Christian cross

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Against black pagans, Turks, and Saracens:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And toil'd with works of war, retired himself

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: To Italy; and there at Venice gave

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: His body to that pleasant country's earth,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And his pure soul unto his captain Christ,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Under whose colours he had fought so long.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Why, bishop, is Norfolk dead?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: As surely as I live, my lord.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Your differences shall all rest under gage

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Till we assign you to your days of trial.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK, attended

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To the possession of thy royal hand:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Ascend his throne, descending now from him;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And long live Henry, fourth of that name!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Marry. God forbid!

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Worst in this royal presence may I speak,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Yet best beseeming me to speak the truth.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Would God that any in this noble presence

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Were enough noble to be upright judge

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Of noble Richard! then true noblesse would

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Learn him forbearance from so foul a wrong.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: What subject can give sentence on his king?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And who sits here that is not Richard's subject?

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Thieves are not judged but they are by to hear,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Although apparent guilt be seen in them;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And shall the figure of God's majesty,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: His captain, steward, deputy-elect,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Anointed, crowned, planted many years,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Be judged by subject and inferior breath,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And he himself not present? O, forfend it, God,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: That in a Christian climate souls refined

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Should show so heinous, black, obscene a deed!

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: I speak to subjects, and a subject speaks,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Stirr'd up by God, thus boldly for his king:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Is a foul traitor to proud Hereford's king:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And if you crown him, let me prophesy:

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The blood of English shall manure the ground,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And future ages groan for this foul act;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Peace shall go sleep with Turks and infidels,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: And in this seat of peace tumultuous wars

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Shall kin with kin and kind with kind confound;

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Shall here inhabit, and this land be call'd

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: O, if you raise this house against this house,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: It will the woefullest division prove

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: That ever fell upon this cursed earth.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Prevent it, resist it, let it not be so,

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Lest child, child's children, cry against you woe!

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Of capital treason we arrest you here.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: To keep him safely till his day of trial.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Fetch hither Richard, that in common view

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: He may surrender; so we shall proceed

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Without suspicion.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I will be his conduct.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Lords, you that here are under our arrest,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Procure your sureties for your days of answer.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Little are we beholding to your love,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And little look'd for at your helping hands.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Re-enter DUKE OF YORK, with KING RICHARD II, and Officers bearing the regalia

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Alack, why am I sent for to a king,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Before I have shook off the regal thoughts

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To this submission. Yet I well remember

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The favours of these men: were they not mine?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So Judas did to Christ: but he, in twelve,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God save the king! Will no man say amen?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Am I both priest and clerk? well then, amen.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God save the king! although I be not he;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To do what service am I sent for hither?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To do that office of thine own good will

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which tired majesty did make thee offer,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The resignation of thy state and crown

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To Henry Bolingbroke.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Here cousin:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: On this side my hand, and on that side yours.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now is this golden crown like a deep well

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That owes two buckets, filling one another,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The emptier ever dancing in the air,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The other down, unseen and full of water:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That bucket down and full of tears am I,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I thought you had been willing to resign.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: You may my glories and my state depose,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But not my griefs; still am I king of those.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Part of your cares you give me with your crown.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My care is loss of care, by old care done;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Your care is gain of care, by new care won:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The cares I give I have, though given away;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They tend the crown, yet still with me they stay.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Are you contented to resign the crown?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Therefore no no, for I resign to thee.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now mark me, how I will undo myself;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I give this heavy weight from off my head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The pride of kingly sway from out my heart;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own tears I wash away my balm,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own hands I give away my crown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own tongue deny my sacred state,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With mine own breath release all duty's rites:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: All pomp and majesty I do forswear;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My manors, rents, revenues I forego;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And soon lie Richard in an earthly pit!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And send him many years of sunshine days!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What more remains?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: No more, but that you read

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: These accusations and these grievous crimes

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Committed by your person and your followers

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Against the state and profit of this land;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That, by confessing them, the souls of men

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: May deem that you are worthily deposed.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Must I do so? and must I ravel out

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If thy offences were upon record,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: There shouldst thou find one heinous article,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Containing the deposing of a king

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And cracking the strong warrant of an oath,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nay, all of you that stand and look upon,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whilst that my wretchedness doth bait myself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Showing an outward pity; yet you Pilates

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And water cannot wash away your sin.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet salt water blinds them not so much

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But they can see a sort of traitors here.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nay, if I turn mine eyes upon myself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I find myself a traitor with the rest;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For I have given here my soul's consent

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To undeck the pompous body of a king;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Made glory base and sovereignty a slave,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Proud majesty a subject, state a peasant.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No, not that name was given me at the font,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But 'tis usurp'd: alack the heavy day,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That I have worn so many winters out,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And know not now what name to call myself!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O that I were a mockery king of snow,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Standing before the sun of Bolingbroke,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To melt myself away in water-drops!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Good king, great king, and yet not greatly good,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: An if my word be sterling yet in England,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let it command a mirror hither straight,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That it may show me what a face I have,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since it is bankrupt of his majesty.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exit an attendant

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The commons will not then be satisfied.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: When I do see the very book indeed

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Re-enter Attendant, with a glass

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Give me the glass, and therein will I read.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: No deeper wrinkles yet? hath sorrow struck

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So many blows upon this face of mine,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Like to my followers in prosperity,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That every day under his household roof

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Was this the face that faced so many follies,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A brittle glory shineth in this face:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As brittle as the glory is the face;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dashes the glass against the ground

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The shadow or your face.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Say that again.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: 'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And these external manners of laments

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Are merely shadows to the unseen grief

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That swells with silence in the tortured soul;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: There lies the substance: and I thank thee, king,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For thy great bounty, that not only givest

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Me cause to wail but teachest me the way

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And then be gone and trouble you no more.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shall I obtain it?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Name it, fair cousin.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: 'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For when I was a king, my flatterers

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Were then but subjects; being now a subject,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I have a king here to my flatterer.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Being so great, I have no need to beg.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Yet ask.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And shall I have?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You shall.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then give me leave to go.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Whither?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whither you will, so I were from your sights.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: O, good! convey? conveyers are you all,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt KING RICHARD II, some Lords, and a Guard

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: On Wednesday next we solemnly set down

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Our coronation: lords, prepare yourselves.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt all except the BISHOP OF CARLISLE, the Abbot of Westminster, and DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: A woeful pageant have we here beheld.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: The woe's to come; the children yet unborn.

speaker: BISHOP OF CARLISLE
text_entry: Shall feel this day as sharp to them as thorn.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: You holy clergymen, is there no plot

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: My lord,

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Before I freely speak my mind herein,

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: You shall not only take the sacrament

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: To bury mine intents, but also to effect

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Whatever I shall happen to devise.

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: I see your brows are full of discontent,

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Your hearts of sorrow and your eyes of tears:

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Come home with me to supper; and I'll lay

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: A plot shall show us all a merry day.

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: SCENE I. London. A street leading to the Tower.

speaker: Abbot
text_entry: Enter QUEEN and Ladies

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: This way the king will come; this is the way

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To whose flint bosom my condemned lord

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Here let us rest, if this rebellious earth

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Have any resting for her true king's queen.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD II and Guard

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: But soft, but see, or rather do not see,
