text_entry: My fair rose wither: yet look up, behold,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: That you in pity may dissolve to dew,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And wash him fresh again with true-love tears.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And not King Richard; thou most beauteous inn,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Why should hard-favour'd grief be lodged in thee,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: When triumph is become an alehouse guest?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To think our former state a happy dream;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: From which awaked, the truth of what we are

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, sweet,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To grim Necessity, and he and I

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Will keep a league till death. Hie thee to France

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And cloister thee in some religious house:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our holy lives must win a new world's crown,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which our profane hours here have stricken down.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What, is my Richard both in shape and mind

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Transform'd and weaken'd? hath Bolingbroke deposed

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Thine intellect? hath he been in thy heart?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And wounds the earth, if nothing else, with rage

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To be o'erpower'd; and wilt thou, pupil-like,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Take thy correction mildly, kiss the rod,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And fawn on rage with base humility,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Which art a lion and a king of beasts?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A king of beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I had been still a happy king of men.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Think I am dead and that even here thou takest,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As from my death-bed, thy last living leave.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With good old folks and let them tell thee tales

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of woeful ages long ago betid;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And ere thou bid good night, to quit their griefs,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Tell thou the lamentable tale of me

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And send the hearers weeping to their beds:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For why, the senseless brands will sympathize

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The heavy accent of thy moving tongue

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And in compassion weep the fire out;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And some will mourn in ashes, some coal-black,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For the deposing of a rightful king.

speaker: KING RICHARD II

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And, madam, there is order ta'en for you;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: With all swift speed you must away to France.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Northumberland, thou ladder wherewithal

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The time shall not be many hours of age

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: More than it is ere foul sin gathering head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Shalt break into corruption: thou shalt think,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Though he divide the realm and give thee half,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: It is too little, helping him to all;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And he shall think that thou, which know'st the way

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To plant unrightful kings, wilt know again,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Being ne'er so little urged, another way

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The love of wicked men converts to fear;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That fear to hate, and hate turns one or both

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To worthy danger and deserved death.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My guilt be on my head, and there an end.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Doubly divorced! Bad men, you violate

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A twofold marriage, 'twixt my crown and me,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And then betwixt me and my married wife.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Part us, Northumberland; I toward the north,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My wife to France: from whence, set forth in pomp,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: She came adorned hither like sweet May,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Sent back like Hallowmas or short'st of day.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And must we be divided? must we part?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ay, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Banish us both and send the king with me.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That were some love but little policy.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Then whither he goes, thither let me go.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So two, together weeping, make one woe.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Better far off than near, be ne'er the near.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: So longest way shall have the longest moans.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Twice for one step I'll groan, the way being short,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And piece the way out with a heavy heart.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Come, come, in wooing sorrow let's be brief,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since, wedding it, there is such length in grief;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: One kiss shall stop our mouths, and dumbly part;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To take on me to keep and kill thy heart.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: So, now I have mine own again, be gone,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: That I might strive to kill it with a groan.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We make woe wanton with this fond delay:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Once more, adieu; the rest let sorrow say.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE II. The DUKE OF YORK's palace.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK and DUCHESS OF YORK

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: My lord, you told me you would tell the rest,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: When weeping made you break the story off,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: of our two cousins coming into London.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Where did I leave?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: At that sad stop, my lord,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Then, as I said, the duke, great Bolingbroke,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which his aspiring rider seem'd to know,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: With slow but stately pace kept on his course,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whilst all tongues cried 'God save thee,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Bolingbroke!'

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: You would have thought the very windows spake,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So many greedy looks of young and old

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Through casements darted their desiring eyes

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Upon his visage, and that all the walls

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: With painted imagery had said at once

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: 'Jesu preserve thee! welcome, Bolingbroke!'

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whilst he, from the one side to the other turning,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Bareheaded, lower than his proud steed's neck,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Bespake them thus: 'I thank you, countrymen:'

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And thus still doing, thus he pass'd along.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alack, poor Richard! where rode he the whilst?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As in a theatre, the eyes of men,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: After a well-graced actor leaves the stage,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Are idly bent on him that enters next,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thinking his prattle to be tedious;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!'

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which with such gentle sorrow he shook off,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His face still combating with tears and smiles,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The badges of his grief and patience,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That had not God, for some strong purpose, steel'd

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The hearts of men, they must perforce have melted

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And barbarism itself have pitied him.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But heaven hath a hand in these events,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To whose high will we bound our calm contents.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whose state and honour I for aye allow.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Here comes my son Aumerle.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Aumerle that was;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But that is lost for being Richard's friend,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And, madam, you must call him Rutland now:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I am in parliament pledge for his truth

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And lasting fealty to the new-made king.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Welcome, my son: who are the violets now

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That strew the green lap of the new come spring?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not:

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: God knows I had as lief be none as one.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Well, bear you well in this new spring of time,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Lest you be cropp'd before you come to prime.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: What news from Oxford? hold those justs and triumphs?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: For aught I know, my lord, they do.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: You will be there, I know.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: If God prevent not, I purpose so.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: What seal is that, that hangs without thy bosom?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Yea, look'st thou pale? let me see the writing.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My lord, 'tis nothing.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: No matter, then, who see it;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: I do beseech your grace to pardon me:

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: It is a matter of small consequence,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Which for some reasons I would not have seen.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which for some reasons, sir, I mean to see.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I fear, I fear,--

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What should you fear?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: 'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Bound to himself! what doth he with a bond

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That he is bound to? Wife, thou art a fool.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Boy, let me see the writing.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: I do beseech you, pardon me; I may not show it.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I will be satisfied; let me see it, I say.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: He plucks it out of his bosom and reads it

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What is the matter, my lord?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Ho! who is within there?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Saddle my horse.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: God for his mercy, what treachery is here!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Why, what is it, my lord?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now, by mine honour, by my life, by my troth,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I will appeach the villain.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What is the matter?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Peace, foolish woman.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I will not peace. What is the matter, Aumerle.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Good mother, be content; it is no more

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Than my poor life must answer.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Thy life answer!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Bring me my boots: I will unto the king.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Re-enter Servant with boots

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Strike him, Aumerle. Poor boy, thou art amazed.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Hence, villain! never more come in my sight.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Give me my boots, I say.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Why, York, what wilt thou do?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Have we more sons? or are we like to have?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And rob me of a happy mother's name?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thou fond mad woman,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And interchangeably set down their hands,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To kill the king at Oxford.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: He shall be none;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: We'll keep him here: then what is that to him?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Away, fond woman! were he twenty times my son,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I would appeach him.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Hadst thou groan'd for him

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That I have been disloyal to thy bed,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And that he is a bastard, not thy son:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Sweet York, sweet husband, be not of that mind:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: He is as like thee as a man may be,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Not like to me, or any of my kin,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And yet I love him.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Make way, unruly woman!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Spur post, and get before him to the king,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I'll not be long behind; though I be old,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I doubt not but to ride as fast as York:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And never will I rise up from the ground

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away, be gone!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: SCENE III. A royal palace.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE, HENRY PERCY, and other Lords

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: 'Tis full three months since I did see him last;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If any plague hang over us, 'tis he.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I would to God, my lords, he might be found:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Inquire at London, 'mongst the taverns there,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: For there, they say, he daily doth frequent,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With unrestrained loose companions,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Even such, they say, as stand in narrow lanes,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And beat our watch, and rob our passengers;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which he, young wanton and effeminate boy,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Takes on the point of honour to support

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So dissolute a crew.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: My lord, some two days since I saw the prince,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And what said the gallant?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: His answer was, he would unto the stews,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And from the common'st creature pluck a glove,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And wear it as a favour; and with that

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As dissolute as desperate; yet through both

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: May happily bring forth. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF AUMERLE

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Where is the king?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What means our cousin, that he stares and looks

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So wildly?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: God save your grace! I do beseech your majesty,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: To have some conference with your grace alone.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt HENRY PERCY and Lords

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What is the matter with our cousin now?

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: For ever may my knees grow to the earth,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouth

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Unless a pardon ere I rise or speak.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Intended or committed was this fault?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If on the first, how heinous e'er it be,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To win thy after-love I pardon thee.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Then give me leave that I may turn the key,

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: That no man enter till my tale be done.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Have thy desire.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: [Within]  My liege, beware; look to thyself;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thou hast a traitor in thy presence there.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Villain, I'll make thee safe.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Drawing

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: [Within]  Open the door, secure, foolhardy king:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Shall I for love speak treason to thy face?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Open the door, or I will break it open.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What is the matter, uncle? speak;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Recover breath; tell us how near is danger,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That we may arm us to encounter it.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Peruse this writing here, and thou shalt know

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The treason that my haste forbids me show.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pass'd:

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: I do repent me; read not my name there

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: My heart is not confederate with my hand.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: It was, villain, ere thy hand did set it down.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I tore it from the traitor's bosom, king;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Fear, and not love, begets his penitence:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O heinous, strong and bold conspiracy!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: O loyal father of a treacherous son!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: From when this stream through muddy passages

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Hath held his current and defiled himself!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Thy overflow of good converts to bad,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And thy abundant goodness shall excuse

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: This deadly blot in thy digressing son.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And he shall spend mine honour with his shame,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The traitor lives, the true man's put to death.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: [Within]  What ho, my liege! for God's sake,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: let me in.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Speak with me, pity me, open the door.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: A beggar begs that never begg'd before.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.'

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My dangerous cousin, let your mother in:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: If thou do pardon, whosoever pray,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: More sins for this forgiveness prosper may.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: This fester'd joint cut off, the rest rest sound;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: This let alone will all the rest confound.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Enter DUCHESS OF YORK

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: O king, believe not this hard-hearted man!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Love loving not itself none other can.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Sweet York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Rise up, good aunt.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Not yet, I thee beseech:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: For ever will I walk upon my knees,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And never see day that the happy sees,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy.

speaker: DUKE OF AUMERLE
text_entry: Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Against them both my true joints bended be.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Ill mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: He prays but faintly and would be denied;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: We pray with heart and soul and all beside:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: His weary joints would gladly rise, I know;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Ours of true zeal and deep integrity.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That mercy which true prayer ought to have.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Good aunt, stand up.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Nay, do not say, 'stand up;'

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.'

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: 'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I never long'd to hear a word till now;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: The word is short, but not so short as sweet;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That set'st the word itself against the word!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: The chopping French we do not understand.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Good aunt, stand up.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I do not sue to stand;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: But makes one pardon strong.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With all my heart

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I pardon him.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: A god on earth thou art.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But for our trusty brother-in-law and the abbot,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With all the rest of that consorted crew,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Destruction straight shall dog them at the heels.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Good uncle, help to order several powers

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: They shall not live within this world, I swear,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But I will have them, if I once know where.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Uncle, farewell: and, cousin too, adieu:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Your mother well hath pray'd, and prove you true.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Come, my old son: I pray God make thee new.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Enter EXTON and Servant

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Didst thou not mark the king, what words he spake,

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: 'Have I no friend will rid me of this living fear?'

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Was it not so?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: These were his very words.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: 'Have I no friend?' quoth he: he spake it twice,

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: And urged it twice together, did he not?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He did.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: And speaking it, he wistly look'd on me,

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: And who should say, 'I would thou wert the man'

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: That would divorce this terror from my heart;'

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Meaning the king at Pomfret. Come, let's go:

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: I am the king's friend, and will rid his foe.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: SCENE V. Pomfret castle.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I have been studying how I may compare

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This prison where I live unto the world:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And for because the world is populous

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And here is not a creature but myself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I cannot do it; yet I'll hammer it out.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My brain I'll prove the female to my soul,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My soul the father; and these two beget

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A generation of still-breeding thoughts,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And these same thoughts people this little world,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In humours like the people of this world,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For no thought is contented. The better sort,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As thoughts of things divine, are intermix'd

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With scruples and do set the word itself

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Against the word:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As thus, 'Come, little ones,' and then again,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: 'It is as hard to come as for a camel

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.'

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Unlikely wonders; how these vain weak nails

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: May tear a passage through the flinty ribs

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That they are not the first of fortune's slaves,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor shall not be the last; like silly beggars

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That many have and others must sit there;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And in this thought they find a kind of ease,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Bearing their own misfortunes on the back

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of such as have before endured the like.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thus play I in one person many people,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And none contented: sometimes am I king;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then treasons make me wish myself a beggar,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And so I am: then crushing penury

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Persuades me I was better when a king;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Then am I king'd again: and by and by

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And straight am nothing: but whate'er I be,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Nor I nor any man that but man is

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With being nothing. Music do I hear?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Music

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Ha, ha! keep time: how sour sweet music is,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: When time is broke and no proportion kept!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So is it in the music of men's lives.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And here have I the daintiness of ear

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But for the concord of my state and time

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Had not an ear to hear my true time broke.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I wasted time, and now doth time waste me;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For now hath time made me his numbering clock:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whereto my finger, like a dial's point,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Show minutes, times, and hours: but my time

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's proud joy,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This music mads me; let it sound no more;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For though it have holp madmen to their wits,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: In me it seems it will make wise men mad.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For 'tis a sign of love; and love to Richard

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Is a strange brooch in this all-hating world.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter a Groom of the Stable

speaker: Groom
text_entry: Hail, royal prince!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thanks, noble peer;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What art thou? and how comest thou hither,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Where no man never comes but that sad dog

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That brings me food to make misfortune live?

speaker: Groom
text_entry: I was a poor groom of thy stable, king,

speaker: Groom
text_entry: When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York,

speaker: Groom
text_entry: With much ado at length have gotten leave

speaker: Groom
text_entry: To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.

speaker: Groom
text_entry: O, how it yearn'd my heart when I beheld

speaker: Groom
text_entry: In London streets, that coronation-day,

speaker: Groom
text_entry: When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary,

speaker: Groom
text_entry: That horse that thou so often hast bestrid,

speaker: Groom
text_entry: That horse that I so carefully have dress'd!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Rode he on Barbary? Tell me, gentle friend,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How went he under him?

speaker: Groom
text_entry: So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That jade hath eat bread from my royal hand;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This hand hath made him proud with clapping him.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Would he not stumble? would he not fall down,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since pride must have a fall, and break the neck

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Of that proud man that did usurp his back?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Forgiveness, horse! why do I rail on thee,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Since thou, created to be awed by man,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wast born to bear? I was not made a horse;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And yet I bear a burthen like an ass,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Spurr'd, gall'd and tired by jouncing Bolingbroke.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter Keeper, with a dish

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: Fellow, give place; here is no longer stay.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: If thou love me, 'tis time thou wert away.

speaker: Groom
text_entry: What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.

speaker: Groom
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: My lord, will't please you to fall to?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, who

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: lately came from the king, commands the contrary.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The devil take Henry of Lancaster and thee!

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Beats the keeper

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: Help, help, help!

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: Enter EXTON and Servants, armed

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: How now! what means death in this rude assault?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Villain, thy own hand yields thy death's instrument.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Snatching an axe from a Servant and killing him

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Go thou, and fill another room in hell.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: He kills another. Then Exton strikes him down

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: That staggers thus my person. Exton, thy fierce hand

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Hath with the king's blood stain'd the king's own land.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Mount, mount, my soul! thy seat is up on high;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward, here to die.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Dies

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: As full of valour as of royal blood:

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good!

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: For now the devil, that told me I did well,

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Says that this deed is chronicled in hell.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: This dead king to the living king I'll bear

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Take hence the rest, and give them burial here.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: SCENE VI. Windsor castle.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Flourish. Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE, DUKE OF YORK, with other Lords, and Attendants

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Kind uncle York, the latest news we hear

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Is that the rebels have consumed with fire

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter NORTHUMBERLAND

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Welcome, my lord what is the news?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: First, to thy sacred state wish I all happiness.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The next news is, I have to London sent

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt, and Kent:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The manner of their taking may appear

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: At large discoursed in this paper here.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter LORD FITZWATER

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: My lord, I have from Oxford sent to London

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: The heads of Brocas and Sir Bennet Seely,

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: Two of the dangerous consorted traitors

speaker: LORD FITZWATER
text_entry: That sought at Oxford thy dire overthrow.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter HENRY PERCY, and the BISHOP OF CARLISLE

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: The grand conspirator, Abbot of Westminster,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: With clog of conscience and sour melancholy

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Hath yielded up his body to the grave;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: But here is Carlisle living, to abide

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Carlisle, this is your doom:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Choose out some secret place, some reverend room,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: More than thou hast, and with it joy thy life;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: So as thou livest in peace, die free from strife:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: For though mine enemy thou hast ever been,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: High sparks of honour in thee have I seen.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter EXTON, with persons bearing a coffin

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Great king, within this coffin I present

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: The mightiest of thy greatest enemies,

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: A deed of slander with thy fatal hand

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Upon my head and all this famous land.

speaker: EXTON
text_entry: From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: They love not poison that do poison need,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I hate the murderer, love him murdered.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But neither my good word nor princely favour:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: With Cain go wander through shades of night,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And never show thy head by day nor light.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Lords, I protest, my soul is full of woe,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: That blood should sprinkle me to make me grow:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Come, mourn with me for that I do lament,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And put on sullen black incontinent:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I'll make a voyage to the Holy Land,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To wash this blood off from my guilty hand:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: March sadly after; grace my mournings here;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: In weeping after this untimely bier.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Exeunt
